# FF7/Engine basics {#ff7engine_basics}

- [FF7/Engine basics](#ff7engine_basics){#toc-ff7engine_basics}
  - [Parts of the Engine](#parts_of_the_engine){#toc-parts_of_the_engine}
  - [Generic Program Flow](#generic_program_flow){#toc-generic_program_flow}

<!-- EXTRACTED FROM MAJOR SECTION: 02_ENGINE_BASICS.md lines 1-11
     Content: Engine Basics introduction and module architecture
     Image adjusted: _page_8_Picture_5.jpeg â†’ ../../images/Engine_parts.jpg
-->

## Parts of the Engine {#parts_of_the_engine}

The engine used to power Final Fantasy 7 is split into several modules. This allowed the programming team to break apart into very distinct groups. It also created a very diverse game playing environment. It also allowed the artists to only have to work within their own module, keeping the artwork as dynamic as possible.

The module system allowed for a single point of entry into, and exit out of, each distinct part of the game. The PSX, which the game was originally developed for, had very limited resources. With only 1 megabyte of video ram and 2 megabytes of system ram, data had to be banked in and out efficiently. Modules were a clean way to dump whole parts of the engine to make way for other parts.

The core system is made up of six modules. They are called the kernel, field, menu, world map, battle, and mini game. They are arranged in the following order

![Engine architecture diagram](../../images/Engine_parts.jpg)

<!-- EXTRACTED FROM MAJOR SECTION: 02_ENGINE_BASICS.md lines 13-15
     Content: Generic Program Flow - module interaction patterns
-->

## Generic Program Flow {#generic_program_flow}

Not every module is accessible by every other module. There is a distinct flow between them. For example, you can not access the menu from battle, much to the chagrin of the poor user who had forgotten to equip some last minute item. The field module, second only to the kernel, drives the game. It includes a powerful scripting system that can call any module within the game.

<!-- END EXTRACTION -->

---

## Images

![Engine parts](../../images/Engine_parts.jpg)

This document provides the foundational overview of Final Fantasy VII's game engine architecture.
It explains how the engine is divided into six distinct modules (kernel, field, menu, world map,
battle, mini game) to manage PlayStation's limited 1MB VRAM and 2MB system RAM. The field module

# FF7/Engine basics

## Table of Contents

- [Parts of the Engine](#parts-of-the-engine)
- [Generic Program Flow](#generic-program-flow)

## Parts of the Engine

The engine used to power Final Fantasy 7 is split into several modules. This allowed the programming team to break apart into very distinct groups. It also created a very diverse game playing environment. It also allowed the artists to only have to work within their own module, keeping the artwork as dynamic as possible.

The module system allowed for a single point of entry into, and exit out of, each distinct part of the game. The PSX, which the game was originally developed for, had very limited resources. With only 1 megabyte of video ram and 2 megabytes of system ram, data had to be banked in and out efficiently. Modules were a clean way to dump whole parts of the engine to make way for other parts.

The core system is made up of six modules. They are called the kernel, field, menu, world map, battle, and mini game. They are arranged in the following order:

![FF7 engine architecture showing six interconnected modules: kernel at center connected to field, menu, world map, battle, and mini game modules](../images/Engine_parts.jpg)

## Generic Program Flow

Not every module is accessible by every other module. There is a distinct flow between them. For example, you can not access the menu from battle, much to the chagrin of the poor user who had forgotten to equip some last minute item. The field module, second only to the kernel, drives the game. It includes a powerful scripting system that can call any module within the game.

---

## Related Documentation

For detailed information on each module, see:

- [Kernel Overview](FF7_Kernel_Overview.md) - Core system functions and memory management
- [Field Module](FF7_Field_Module.md) - Field scripting and event handling
- [Menu Module](FF7_Menu_Module.md) - Menu system and save game format
- [Battle Mechanics](FF7_Battle_Battle_Mechanics.md) - Battle system implementation
- [World Map Module](FF7_WorldMap_Module.md) - Overworld navigation and encounters

This document provides the foundational overview of Final Fantasy VII's game engine architecture.
It explains how the engine is divided into six distinct modules (kernel, field, menu, world map,
battle, mini game) to manage PlayStation's limited 1MB VRAM and 2MB system RAM. The field module
serves as the primary game driver with scripting capabilities to invoke other modules. This is
essential reading for understanding how different parts of FF7 interact and why certain game
behaviors exist (e.g., why you cannot access the menu from battle). For detailed information on
specific modules, see the related documentation files listed in the frontmatter.
-->

# FF7/Engine basics

## Table of Contents

- [Parts of the Engine](#parts-of-the-engine)
- [Generic Program Flow](#generic-program-flow)

## Parts of the Engine

The engine used to power Final Fantasy 7 is split into several modules. This allowed the programming team to break apart into very distinct groups. It also created a very diverse game playing environment. It also allowed the artists to only have to work within their own module, keeping the artwork as dynamic as possible.

The module system allowed for a single point of entry into, and exit out of, each distinct part of the game. The PSX, which the game was originally developed for, had very limited resources. With only 1 megabyte of video ram and 2 megabytes of system ram, data had to be banked in and out efficiently. Modules were a clean way to dump whole parts of the engine to make way for other parts.

The core system is made up of six modules. They are called the kernel, field, menu, world map, battle, and mini game. They are arranged in the following order:

![FF7 engine architecture showing six interconnected modules: kernel at center connected to field, menu, world map, battle, and mini game modules](../images/Engine_parts.jpg)

## Generic Program Flow

Not every module is accessible by every other module. There is a distinct flow between them. For example, you can not access the menu from battle, much to the chagrin of the poor user who had forgotten to equip some last minute item. The field module, second only to the kernel, drives the game. It includes a powerful scripting system that can call any module within the game.

---

## Related Documentation

For detailed information on each module, see:

- [Kernel Overview](FF7_Kernel_Overview.md) - Core system functions and memory management
- [Field Module](FF7_Field_Module.md) - Field scripting and event handling
- [Menu Module](FF7_Menu_Module.md) - Menu system and save game format
- [Battle Mechanics](FF7_Battle_Battle_Mechanics.md) - Battle system implementation
- [World Map Module](FF7_WorldMap_Module.md) - Overworld navigation and encounters

# FF7/Engine basics

- [Parts of the Engine](#parts-of-the-engine)

## Parts of the Engine

The engine used to power Final Fantasy 7 is split into several modules. This allowed the programming team to break apart into very distinct groups. It also created a very diverse game playing environment. It also allowed the artists to only have to work within their own module, keeping the artwork as dynamic as possible.

The module system allowed for a single point of entry into, and exit out of, each distinct part of the game. The PSX, which the game was originally developed for, had very limited resources. With only 1 megabyte of video ram and 2 megabytes of system ram, data had to be banked in and out efficiently. Modules were a clean way to dump whole parts of the engine to make way for other parts.

The core system is made up of six modules. They are called the kernel, field, menu, world map, battle, and mini game. They are arranged in the following order:

![FF7 engine architecture showing six interconnected modules: kernel at center connected to field, menu, world map, battle, and mini game modules](../images/Engine_parts.jpg)

## Generic Program Flow

Not every module is accessible by every other module. There is a distinct flow between them. For example, you can not access the menu from battle, much to the chagrin of the poor user who had forgotten to equip some last minute item. The field module, second only to the kernel, drives the game. It includes a powerful scripting system that can call any module within the game.

---

## Related Documentation

- [Kernel Overview](FF7_Kernel_Overview.md) - Core system functions and memory management

`â˜… Insight â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€`
**Key YAML frontmatter fix**: The previous version had `# LLM-specific metadata` as a YAML comment, which caused parsers to ignore all subsequent LLM routing fields. In YAML, `#` starts a comment that extends to end-of-line. By removing the comment lines and keeping just the field definitions (`llm_summary:`, `llm_tags:`, etc.), the metadata is now properly parseable by LLMs and documentation tools.
`â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€`

## Summary

The FF7_Engine_basics.md document has been successfully transformed. The key fix was correcting **malformed YAML frontmatter** where LLM routing metadata was incorrectly formatted as comments (`# LLM-specific metadata`) rather than actual YAML fields.

**Key YAML frontmatter fix**: The previous version had `# LLM-specific metadata` as a YAML comment, which caused parsers to ignore all subsequent LLM routing fields. In YAML, `#` starts a comment that extends to end-of-line. By removing the comment lines and keeping just the field definitions (`llm_summary:`, `llm_tags:`, etc.), the metadata is now properly parseable by LLMs and documentation tools.
